title: 1873-B
statement: B. Good Kidtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputSlavic is preparing a present for a friend's birthday. He has an array $$$a$$$ of $$$n$$$ digits and the present will be the product of all these digits. Because Slavic is a good kid who wants to make the biggest product possible, he wants to add $$$1$$$ to exactly one of his digits.What is the maximum product Slavic can make?InputThe first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\leq t \\leq 10^4$$$) — the number of test cases.The first line of each test case contains a single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\leq n \\leq 9$$$) — the number of digits.The second line of each test case contains $$$n$$$ space-separated integers $$$a_i$$$ ($$$0 \\leq a_i \\leq 9$$$) — the digits in the array.OutputFor each test case, output a single integer — the maximum product Slavic can make, by adding $$$1$$$ to exactly one of his digits.ExampleInput442 2 1 230 1 254 3 2 3 499 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9Output16 2 432 430467210

processed.result:
You are given an array of digits. You can add 1 to exactly one digit in the array. What is the largest possible product of all the digits after making this change?

Input:

* The first line contains the number of test cases, $t$.
* For each test case:
    * The first line contains the number of digits, $n$.
    * The second line contains $n$ space-separated digits.

Output:

* For each test case, output the maximum possible product.
You are given a list of numbers. You can add 1 to exactly one number in the list. What is the largest possible product of all the numbers in the list after you make this change?
